item.title: Bruce Rauner's Grandparents Were Immigrants
item.description:
My grandparents were proud immigrants to the United States of America, here to Illinois in the late 1800s. My grandparents did not speak English when they were young.

— Bruce Rauner, signing ceremony for TRUST Act (SB31)

Claims:

Bruce Rauner's Grandparents Were Immigrants
The Truth:
Census reports, as well as Rauner’s previous statements, refute this.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
We have no reason to doubt that Rauner’s grandparents meant the world to him. But the Census plainly refutes his claim that they were immigrants. What’s more, both couldn’t have come to the U.S. in the late 1800s because they weren’t even born until the early 1900s — in Wisconsin, not Sweden. Rauner’s assertion in August that his grandparents immigrated to Illinois is yet another inaccuracy.

item.title: IL SB 1 Is a Bailout of Chicago's Teacher Pension System
item.description:
As written, the bill includes a bailout of Chicago’s broken teacher pension system.

— Bruce Rauner, press release

Claims:

IL SB 1 Is a Bailout of Chicago's Teacher Pension System
The Truth:
Not true.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
The bill’s Chicago pension component can’t be called a “bailout” or even a perk because it only gives CPS what every other school district already has.
